paragraphs.name: a810
paragraphs.text: Introducing a brand new pub.dev

paragraphs.name: 919e
paragraphs.text: Redesigned for high-quality, multiplatform packages

paragraphs.name: 3a98
paragraphs.text: Today we’re launching a brand new pub.dev site. It features new scoring metrics to give you a better understanding of potentially useful packages, and to provide package publishers with more actionable feedback on how to improve package quality. To help you find packages that support all the platforms you’re interested in, we’ve added support for identifying and searching for multiplatform packages. And overall we’ve redesigned the UI, aiming for a delightful and elegant experience that’s consistent with our dart.dev and dartpad.dev sites.

paragraphs.name: 8e00
paragraphs.text: The new pub.dev site

metadata.alt: A screenshot of the page at https://pub.dev

paragraphs.text: Finding the best packages for your needs

With nearly 7,000 new packages published over the past year, you have no shortage of options when looking for packages to extend the functionality of your apps. But with so many packages to choose from, naturally you want the most liked, highest quality, and most popular packages to bubble to the surface. To support better package search results, we’ve redesigned the scoring system in pub.dev around three dimensions:

paragraphs.name: 3cca
paragraphs.text: The three scoring dimensions for a pub package

metadata.alt: Screenshot of a package summary: 552 likes; 100/110 pub points; 98% popularity

paragraphs.name: bfa6
paragraphs.text: Likes: A measure of how many developers have liked a package. This provides a raw measure of the overall sentiment toward a package.

paragraphs.name: cfd9
paragraphs.text: Pub points: A new measure of quality. This includes several dimensions of quality such as code style, platform support, and maintainability. More about this below.

paragraphs.name: ea34
paragraphs.text: Popularity: A measure of how many developers use a package. This reflects the number of apps that depend on the package over the past sixty days. The normalized scale ranges from 100% (the most used package) to 0% (the least used package), but we’re investigating whether we can provide absolute usage counts in a future version.
We hope that these new dimensions help both package consumers who are looking for packages to depend on, and package publishers working on shipping a high quality packages.

paragraphs.name: 29d6
paragraphs.text: Measuring quality with pub points

With likes and popularity providing community-sourced, subjective measures, the goal of pub points is to provide a close approximation of measurable, objective quality. This isn’t easy; developers perceive quality in a variety of ways, but we still believe that most developers look for core traits that we can measure. The previous pub.dev scoring model was based on subtracting points for issues. The new scoring model reverses this approach, instead awarding points based on traits in five categories:

paragraphs.name: 12a2
paragraphs.text: Pub points overview with categories and checks, as well as points awarded

metadata.alt: Screenshot: Pub points overview for a package

paragraphs.name: 3b02
paragraphs.text: Follow Dart file conventions: Follow best practices around pubspec, readme, and changelog files

paragraphs.name: 4f18
paragraphs.text: Provide documentation: Provide API documentation and an illustrative example
Support multiple platforms: Support as many Dart and Flutter platforms as possible

paragraphs.name: d325
paragraphs.text: Pass static analysis: Provide code that is free from errors, warnings, and lints

paragraphs.name: 31f1
paragraphs.text: Support up-to-date dependencies: Have dependency constraints that support the latest Dart & Flutter SDKs, and the latest package dependencies

paragraphs.name: bb6f
paragraphs.text: We expect to add more checks and categories for pub points over time, raising the ceiling for how many points a package can have. For example, we plan to add a score for supporting null safety when that feature launches. And we’re investigating how to measure maintainability (issue and pull request responsiveness), testability (automated test coverage), and community friendliness (number of contributors, maintainers, etc.). If you have an idea for a great measure, we’d love to hear from you!

paragraphs.name: dd92
paragraphs.text: Supporting multiplatform apps

Both Dart and Flutter excel at creating apps that target multiple platforms. On pub.dev we’ve provide clear platform tags for mobile (iOS and Android) and web platforms, as well as search filters for these platforms:

paragraphs.name: 8f8f
paragraphs.text: Platform filters in search

metadata.alt: Screenshot: Search results for Flutter packages that support both Android and Web

paragraphs.name: 132c
paragraphs.text: To make sure that your package is tagged with the correct platform support, follow the guidance on the pub.dev scoring help page.

paragraphs.name: d7f9
paragraphs.text: We’ll be adding similar support for desktop platforms (macOS, Windows, and Linux) when that advances to a more final state. For now you can find filters for those platforms inside the Advanced search options:

paragraphs.name: 5fbe
paragraphs.text: Desktop platforms in advanced filters

metadata.alt: Screenshot: Search results for Flutter packages that support Android, iOS, and macOS platforms

paragraphs.name: 8dfe
paragraphs.text: An elegant and delightful design

paragraphs.name: 97ea
paragraphs.text: The Dart pub.dev team collaborated with Google Developer Studio, our internal creative team, with Jeremy Sie as the main designer. Alongside functional updates, the team took a considered look at the visual design, sharing their thoughts on the project. With an eye to providing a coherent, accessible, and user-focused experience, we made a range of refinements rooted in Google’s Material Design system. Our aim was to create a lightweight and streamlined interface, allowing for clear and concise workflows for both package publishers and consumers.

paragraphs.name: d2b3
paragraphs.text: The updated design features Material components such as cards and chips that clearly display package details and allow greater transparency into how individual packages function. We updated the typographic system and improved the type scale across the site, bringing greater clarity to search results and improving the way package information is displayed. Components such as package scores have been redesigned to be clearer and structured in a way that makes the scoring process more transparent and easier to understand.
Search showing all three pub.dev scores

paragraphs.name: 31e3
paragraphs.text: We also made changes to the homepage. We knew the ability to quickly search for packages was a core part of the site, but we wanted to improve the experience by surfacing the most useful tools and libraries. We added sections such as Flutter favorites and Most popular packages up front, helping you to quickly explore some of the best packages available. We took a close look at the color palette and art direction, incorporating illustrations and making components such as code examples visually consistent with dart.dev and dartpad.dev.

paragraphs.name: 8d4d
paragraphs.text: Try pub.dev today

paragraphs.name: c316
paragraphs.text: We invite you to try the new pub.dev browse and search experience today, and to use the new scoring dimensions and pub points report.

paragraphs.name: 7d7a
paragraphs.text: If you’re a package developer, we encourage you to view the pub points for your packages, looking for opportunities to improve your packages. For further details on how the scoring system works, see the pub.dev scoring help.

paragraphs.name: fc5e
paragraphs.text: As always, we love feedback. Please leave comments below, or file issues in the pub.dev issue tracker.

paragraphs.name: 30b5
paragraphs.text:
By: Michael Thomsen (Product Manager, Dart) & 
Jeremy Sie (Visual Designer, Google Developer Studio)

topics.name: Programming
topics.description: The good, the bad, the buggy.
